newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian GSM operator Mobistar has 20,000 clients.
newsitem.headline: Belgian GSM operator Mobistar has 20,000 clients.

text.p: Belgian-French company Mobistar, which operates Belgium's second GSM mobile phone network, has signed up 20,000 clients six weeks after its launch, the group said on Tuesday.
Mobistar Managing Director Bernard Ghillebaert told a news conference that Mobistar hoped to have an 11 percent market share by the year 2000 and 25 percent by 2005.
Its first profits should come earlier. "We hope to break even in three to four years," he said.
Rival operator Belgacom Mobile, whose Proximus service was launched in January 1994, now has an estimated 400,000 clients.
Belgacom Mobile is a 75/25 venture between state telephone company Belgacom SA and AirTouch Communications Inc of the U.S..
Belgacom is 49.9 percent owned by a consortium including U.S. Ameritech, Singapore Telecom and Tele Danmark. The rest is owned by the Belgian state.
Mobistar is owned 62 percent by France Telecom. Belgian data communications firm Telinfo NV has 10 percent and a group of eight other Belgian investors 28 percent.
Ghillebaert said that Mobistar had invested 15 billion francs this year, nine billion for the licence to operate the system and six billion for the network.

He also said that it was still in negotiations with Belgacom about the interconnection fees between the two networks. He said Belgacom was asking "substantially more" from Mobistar than France Telecom was asking its French competitors.
